Basic Example for Usage of ceRNAnetsim

Selcen Ari

2019-08-06

basic_usage.Rmd
library(ceRNAnetsim)

You can obtain your own dataset with basic commands as following:

# datapasta::tribble_paste()
gene_expression <- tibble::tribble(
                  ~competing, ~Competing_expression,
                     "Gene1",                 10000,
                     "Gene2",                 10000,
                     "Gene3",                  5000,
                     "Gene4",                 10000,
                     "Gene5",                  5000,
                     "Gene6",                 10000
                  )
gene_expression
#> # A tibble: 6 x 2
#>   competing Competing_expression
#>   <chr>                    <dbl>
#> 1 Gene1                    10000
#> 2 Gene2                    10000
#> 3 Gene3                     5000
#> 4 Gene4                    10000
#> 5 Gene5                     5000
#> 6 Gene6                    10000
# datapasta::tribble_paste()
mirna_expression <- tibble::tribble(
                             ~miRNA, ~miRNA_expression,
                             "Mir1",              1000,
                             "Mir2",              2000
                             )
mirna_expression
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   miRNA miRNA_expression
#>   <chr>            <dbl>
#> 1 Mir1              1000
#> 2 Mir2              2000

Third table should contain miRNA:gene interactions. This table can be as simple as

#datapasta::tribble_paste()
interaction_simple <- tibble::tribble(
                     ~competing, ~miRNA,
                        "Gene1", "Mir1",
                        "Gene2", "Mir1",
                        "Gene3", "Mir1",
                        "Gene4", "Mir1",
                        "Gene4", "Mir2",
                        "Gene5", "Mir2",
                        "Gene6", "Mir2"
                     )
interaction_simple
#> # A tibble: 7 x 2
#>   competing miRNA
#>   <chr>     <chr>
#> 1 Gene1     Mir1 
#> 2 Gene2     Mir1 
#> 3 Gene3     Mir1 
#> 4 Gene4     Mir1 
#> 5 Gene4     Mir2 
#> 6 Gene5     Mir2 
#> 7 Gene6     Mir2
interaction_simple%>%
  inner_join(gene_expression, by = "competing")%>%
  inner_join(mirna_expression, "miRNA")->basic_data

What does ceRNAnetsim do?

ceRNAnetsim processes your dataset as graph object and simulates competing behaviours of targets when steady-state is perturbed via one or more change. Let’s run three steps

1. Handle basic dataset

#Convertion of dataset to graph.

priming_graph(basic_data, competing_count = Competing_expression, miRNA_count =miRNA_expression)
#> Warning in priming_graph(basic_data, competing_count = Competing_expression, : First column is processed as competing and the second as miRNA.
#> # A tbl_graph: 8 nodes and 7 edges
#> #
#> # A rooted tree
#> #
#> # Node Data: 8 x 7 (active)
#>   name  type  node_id initial_count count_pre count_current
#>   <chr> <chr>   <int>         <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1 Gene1 Comp~       1         10000     10000         10000
#> 2 Gene2 Comp~       2         10000     10000         10000
#> 3 Gene3 Comp~       3          5000      5000          5000
#> 4 Gene4 Comp~       4         10000     10000         10000
#> 5 Gene5 Comp~       5          5000      5000          5000
#> 6 Gene6 Comp~       6         10000     10000         10000
#> # ... with 2 more rows, and 1 more variable: changes_variable <chr>
#> #
#> # Edge Data: 7 x 19
#>    from    to Competing_name miRNA_name Competing_expre~ miRNA_expression
#>   <int> <int> <chr>          <chr>                 <dbl>            <dbl>
#> 1     1     7 Gene1          Mir1                  10000             1000
#> 2     2     7 Gene2          Mir1                  10000             1000
#> 3     3     7 Gene3          Mir1                   5000             1000
#> # ... with 4 more rows, and 13 more variables: dummy <dbl>,
#> #   afff_factor <dbl>, degg_factor <dbl>, comp_count_list <list>,
#> #   comp_count_pre <dbl>, comp_count_current <dbl>,
#> #   mirna_count_list <list>, mirna_count_pre <dbl>,
#> #   mirna_count_current <dbl>, mirna_count_per_dep <dbl>,
#> #   effect_current <dbl>, effect_pre <dbl>, effect_list <list>

2. Trigger a change


priming_graph(basic_data, competing_count = Competing_expression, miRNA_count =miRNA_expression)%>%
  update_how(node_name = "Gene2", how=2)
#> Warning in priming_graph(basic_data, competing_count = Competing_expression, : First column is processed as competing and the second as miRNA.
#> # A tbl_graph: 8 nodes and 7 edges
#> #
#> # A rooted tree
#> #
#> # Node Data: 8 x 7 (active)
#>   name  type  node_id initial_count count_pre count_current
#>   <chr> <chr>   <int>         <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1 Gene1 Comp~       1         10000     10000         10000
#> 2 Gene2 Comp~       2         10000     10000         20000
#> 3 Gene3 Comp~       3          5000      5000          5000
#> 4 Gene4 Comp~       4         10000     10000         10000
#> 5 Gene5 Comp~       5          5000      5000          5000
#> 6 Gene6 Comp~       6         10000     10000         10000
#> # ... with 2 more rows, and 1 more variable: changes_variable <chr>
#> #
#> # Edge Data: 7 x 19
#>    from    to Competing_name miRNA_name Competing_expre~ miRNA_expression
#>   <int> <int> <chr>          <chr>                 <dbl>            <dbl>
#> 1     1     7 Gene1          Mir1                  10000             1000
#> 2     2     7 Gene2          Mir1                  10000             1000
#> 3     3     7 Gene3          Mir1                   5000             1000
#> # ... with 4 more rows, and 13 more variables: dummy <dbl>,
#> #   afff_factor <dbl>, degg_factor <dbl>, comp_count_list <list>,
#> #   comp_count_pre <dbl>, comp_count_current <dbl>,
#> #   mirna_count_list <list>, mirna_count_pre <dbl>,
#> #   mirna_count_current <dbl>, mirna_count_per_dep <dbl>,
#> #   effect_current <dbl>, effect_pre <dbl>, effect_list <list>

You can see the current count of Gene2 node is 20000 and its change is specified as “Up” in changes_variable column of node data of graph.

3. Simulate the changes in graph


priming_graph(basic_data, competing_count = Competing_expression, miRNA_count =miRNA_expression)%>%
  update_how(node_name = "Gene2", how=2)%>%
  simulate(cycle = 5)
#> Warning in priming_graph(basic_data, competing_count = Competing_expression, : First column is processed as competing and the second as miRNA.
#> # A tbl_graph: 8 nodes and 7 edges
#> #
#> # A rooted tree
#> #
#> # Node Data: 8 x 7 (active)
#>   name  type  node_id initial_count count_pre count_current
#>   <chr> <chr>   <int>         <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1 Gene1 Comp~       1         10000    10062.        10062.
#> 2 Gene2 Comp~       2         10000    19845.        19845.
#> 3 Gene3 Comp~       3          5000     5031.         5031.
#> 4 Gene4 Comp~       4         10000    10059.        10059.
#> 5 Gene5 Comp~       5          5000     5001.         5001.
#> 6 Gene6 Comp~       6         10000    10002.        10002.
#> # ... with 2 more rows, and 1 more variable: changes_variable <chr>
#> #
#> # Edge Data: 7 x 20
#>    from    to Competing_name miRNA_name Competing_expre~ miRNA_expression
#>   <int> <int> <chr>          <chr>                 <dbl>            <dbl>
#> 1     1     7 Gene1          Mir1                  10000             1000
#> 2     2     7 Gene2          Mir1                  10000             1000
#> 3     3     7 Gene3          Mir1                   5000             1000
#> # ... with 4 more rows, and 14 more variables: dummy <dbl>,
#> #   afff_factor <dbl>, degg_factor <dbl>, comp_count_list <list>,
#> #   comp_count_pre <dbl>, comp_count_current <dbl>,
#> #   mirna_count_list <list>, mirna_count_pre <dbl>,
#> #   mirna_count_current <dbl>, mirna_count_per_dep <dbl>,
#> #   effect_current <dbl>, effect_pre <dbl>, effect_list <list>,
#> #   mirna_count_per_comp <dbl>

Briefly, ceRNAnetsim utilizes the change(s) as trigger and provides regulation of targets according to miRNA:target and target:total target ratios.

See the other vignettes for more information.

  • 3. Simulate the changes in graph
